term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Tambourine.

relation.label: 211.311-7 Single-skin frame drums without handle with membrane nailed to drum
211.311-86 Single-skin frame drums without handle with cord-and-peg bracing
211.311-92 Single-skin frame drums without handle with membrane lapped onto a hoop

term.label: 211.311-7 Single-skin frame drums without handle with membrane nailed to drum
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane nailed to drum.

term.label: 211.311-86 Single-skin frame drums without handle with cord-and-peg bracing
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. Cord-and-peg bracing. the cords are lsced at the lower end to pegs stuck into the wall of the drum. Africa.

term.label: 211.311-92 Single-skin frame drums without handle with membrane lapped onto a hoop
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

term.label: 211.312 Double-skin frame drums without handle
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. It is enclosed by two tightly stretched membranes that are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. North Africa, Portugal.

relation.label: 211.312-7 Double-skin frame drums without handle with membrane nailed to drum

term.label: 211.312-7 Double-skin frame drums without handle with membrane nailed to drum
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. It is enclosed by two tightly stretched membranes that are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane nailed to drum.

term.label: 211.32 Frame drums with handle
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

term.label: 211.321 Single-skin frame drums with handle
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Inuit.

relation.label: 211.321-86 Single-skin frame drums with handle with cord-and-peg bracing
211.321-92 Single-skin frame drums with handle with membrane lapped onto a hoop

term.label: 211.321-86 Single-skin frame drums with handle with cord-and-peg bracing
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum.

term.label: 211.321-92 Single-skin frame drums with handle with membrane lapped onto a hoop
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

term.label: 211.322 Double-skin frame drums with handle
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The body is enclosed by tightly stretched membranes that are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Tibet.

term.label: 212 Rattle drums
term.definition: Tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.1 Vessel rattle drums
term.definition: Drums with single tightly stretched membranes enclosing drum bodies in the form of vessels that are curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membranes are indirectly struck by enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. (Unknown).

term.label: 212.2 Tubular rattle drums
term.definition: Drums with tubular bodies and tightly stretched membranes enclosing both ends. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.21 Cylindrical rattle drums
term.definition: Drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum bodies are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.211 Individual cylindrical rattle drums
term.definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.212 Sets of cylindrical rattle drums
term.definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. Each drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.22 Barrel-shaped rattle drums
term.definition: Drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.221 Individual barrel-shaped rattle drums
term.definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body in which the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.222 Sets of barrel-shaped rattle drums
term.definition: Sets of drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.23 Double-conical rattle drums
term.definition: Drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. (Unknown).

term.label: 212.231 Individual double-conical rattle drums
term.definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.232 Sets of double-conical rattle drums
term.definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.24 Hourglass-shaped rattle drums
term.definition: Drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.241 Individual hourglass-shaped rattle drums
term.definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. India.

term.label: 212.242 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums
term.definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

relation.label: 212.242-7 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums with membrane nailed to drum
212.242-91 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums with membrane lapped onto a ring of cord

term.label: 212.242-7 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums with membrane nailed to drum
term.definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. With membrane nailed to drum.

term.label: 212.242-91 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums with membrane lapped onto a ring of cord
term.definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. With membrane lapped onto a ring of cord.

term.label: 212.3 Frame rattle drums
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

term.label: 212.31 Single-skin frame rattle drums
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

relation.label: 212.31-92 Single-skin frame rattle drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop

term.label: 212.31-92 Single-skin frame rattle drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

term.label: 212.32 Double-skin frame rattle drums
term.definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

relation.label: 212.322 Sets of double-skin frame rattle drums

term.label: 212.321 Individual double-skin frame rattle drums
term.definition: An individual drum in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. India.

term.label: 212.322 Sets of double-skin frame rattle drums
term.definition: Sets of drums in each one of which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle passes through all the drum bodies. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. China.

term.label: 23 Friction drums
term.definition: The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes made to vibrate by friction.

term.label: 231 Friction drums with stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes, made to vibrate by friction. A stick in contact with the membrane is either itself rubbed, or is employed to rub the membrane.

term.label: 231.1 Friction drums with inserted stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction with a stick that passes through a hole in it. The stick is either itself rubbed, or is employed to rub the membrane.

term.label: 231.11 Friction drums with fixed stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane, made to vibrate by friction. A fixed stick makes contact with the membrane, passing through a hole in it. The stick is subjected to friction by rubbing. Africa.

term.label: 231.12 Friction drums with semi-fixed stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction with a stick that passes through a hole in it. The stick is movable to a sufficient extent to rub the membrane when it is itself rubbed by the hand. Africa.

term.label: 231.13 Friction drums with free stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction with a stick that passes through a hole in it. The stick can be moved freely; it is not itself rubbed, but is employed to rub the membrane. Venezuela.

term.label: 231.2 Friction drums with tied stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction. A stick makes contact with the membrane, passing through a hole in it. The stick is tied to the membrane in an upright position. Europe.

term.label: 232 Friction drums with cord
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction. A cord attached to the membrane is rubbed.

relation.label: 232.1 Stationary friction drums with friction cord

term.label: 232.1 Stationary friction drums with friction cord
term.definition: The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes made to vibrate by friction. A cord, attached to the membrane, is rubbed. The drum is held stationary. Europe, Africa.

relation.label: 232.11 Single-skin stationary drums with friction cord

term.label: 232.11 Single-skin stationary drums with friction cord
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched single membrane made to vibrate by friction when a cord, attached to the membrane is rubbed. The drum is held stationary.

relation.label: 232.1 Stationary friction drums with friction cord

term.label: 232.12 Double-skin stationary drums with frictioncord
term.definition: The sound is excited by two tightly stretched membranes made to vibrate by friction when a cord, attached to them, is rubbed. The drum is held stationary.

relation.label: 232.1 Stationary friction drums with friction cord

term.label: 232.2 Friction drum with whirling stick
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction. The drum is whirled on a cord which rubs on a [resined] notch in the holding stick. Waldteufel [cardboard buzzer]. Europe, India, E. Africa.

term.label: 233 Hand friction drums
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction when rubbed by the hand.

term.label: 24 Singing membranes (Kazoos)
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the sound of the membrane modifies that of the voice. Europe, W. Africa.

term.label: 241 Free kazoos
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the sound of the membrane modifies that of the voice. The membrane is incited directly, without the wind first passing through a chamber. Comb-and-paper.

term.label: 242 Tube- or vessel-kazoos
term.definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the sound of the membrane modifies that of the voice. The membrane is placed on top of a tube or box. Africa; while also, E. Asian flutes with a lateral hole sealed by a membrane, exhibit an affinity with the principle of the tube kazoo.

term.label: 3 Chordophones
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points.

term.label: 31 Simple chordophones or zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus.

term.label: 311 Bar zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is bar-shaped; it may be a board placed edgewise.

term.label: 311.1 Musical bows
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved).

term.label: 311.11 ldiochord musical bows
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end.

term.label: 311.111 Mono-idiochord musical bows
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end. New Guinea (Sepik R.), Togo.

term.label: 311.112 Poly-idiochord musical bows or harp-bows
term.definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end. They pass over a toothed stick or bridge. W. Africa (Fan).

term.label: 311.12 Heterochord musical bows
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer.

term.label: 311.121 Mono-heterochord musical bows
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer.

term.label: 311.121.1 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no resonator (the human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator). The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. NB: if a separate, unattached resonator is used, the specimen belongs to 311.121.21.

relation.label: 311.121.11 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator or tuning noose
311.121.12 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator, with tuning noose
311.121.1-5 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 311.121.11 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator or tuning noose
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no tuning noose or resonator (the human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator). The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. Africa (ganza, samuius, to).

term.label: 311.121.12 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator, with tuning noose
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no resonator (the human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator). The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. A fibre noose is passed round the string, dividing it into two sections. South-equatorial Africa (n'kungo, uta).

term.label: 311.121.1-5 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no resonator (the human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator). The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 311.121.2 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral, and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer.

relation.label: 311.121.21 Mono-heterochord musical bows with independent resonator
311.121.22 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached

term.label: 311.121.21 Mono-heterochord musical bows with independent resonator
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with an independent resonator. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. Borneo (busoi).

term.label: 311.121.22 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator that can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer.

relation.label: 311.121.221 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached, without tuning noose
311.121.222 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached with tuning noose

term.label: 311.121.221 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached, without tuning noose
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator that can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. The string has no tuning noose. S. Africa (hade, thomo).

relation.label: 311.121.22 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached

term.label: 311.121.222 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached with tuning noose
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator that can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the bearer. A fibre noose is passed round the string, dividing it into two sections. S. Africa, Madagascar (gubo, hungo, bobre).

relation.label: 311.121.22 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached

term.label: 311.122 Poly-heterochord musical bows
term.definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer.

relation.label: 311.122.1 Poly-heterochord musical bows without tuning noose
311.122.2 Poly-heterochord musical bows with tuning noose

term.label: 311.122.1 Poly-heterochord musical bows without tuning noose
term.definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. The strings have no tuning noose. Oceania (kalove).

term.label: 311.122.2 Poly-heterochord musical bows with tuning noose
term.definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. A fibre noose is passed round the strings, dividing them into two sections. Oceania (pagolo).

term.label: 311.2 Stick zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string carrier is rigid.

term.label: 311.21 Musical bow cum stick
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a stick with one flexible, curved end. India. NB: stick zithers with both ends flexible and curved, like the Basuto bow, are counted as musical bows.

term.label: 311.22 (True) stick zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string carrier is a rigid stick. NB: round sticks which happen to be hollow by chance do not belong on this account to the tube zithers, but are round bar zithers; however, instruments in which a tubular cavity is employed as a true resonator, like the modern Mexican harpa, are tube zithers.

relation.label: 311.221 (True) stick zithers with one resonator gourd
311.222 (True) stick zithers with several resonator gourds

term.label: 311.221 (True) stick zithers with one resonator gourd
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with one gourd resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a rigid stick. India (tuila), Celebes (suleppe).

term.label: 311.222 (True) stick zithers with several resonator gourds
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with several gourd resonators which are not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a rigid stick. India (vina).

term.label: 312 Tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a vaulted surface.

term.label: 312.1 Whole-tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a complete tube.

term.label: 312.11 ldiochord (true) tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a complete tube. The strings are cut from the bark of the tube, remaining attached at each end. Africa and Indonesia (gonra, togo, valiha).

term.label: 312.12 Heterochord (true) tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a complete tube. The strings are of separate material from the tube.

relation.label: 312.121 Heterochord (true) tube zithers without extra resonator
312.122 Heterochord (true) tube zithers with extra resonator

term.label: 312.121 Heterochord (true) tube zithers without extra resonator
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer which is a complete tube. The strings are of separate material from the tube. The instrument has no additional resonator. S. E. Asia (alligator).

term.label: 312.122 Heterochord (true) tube zithers with extra resonator
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid tubular string bearer that is an internode length of bamboo. It is placed inside a resonator which is a palm leaf tied in the shape of a bowl. The resonator is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. Timor.

term.label: 312.2 Half-tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points along the convex surface of a gutter.

term.label: 312.21 ldiochord half-tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points along the convex surface of a gutter. The strings are cut from the bark of the string bearer, remaining attached at each end. Flores.

term.label: 312.22 Heterochord half-tube zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points along the convex surface of a gutter. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. E. Asia.

term.label: 313 Raft zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft.

term.label: 313.1 ldiochord raft zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft. The strings are cut from the bark of the string bearer, remaining attached at each end. India, Upper Guinea, Central Congo.

term.label: 313.2 Heterochord raft zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. N. Malawi region.

relation.label: 313.2-5 Heterochord raft zithers sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 313.2-5 Heterochord raft zithers sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 314 Board zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The ground too, is to be counted as a string bearer.

term.label: 314.1 True board zithers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer.

term.label: 314.11 True board zithers without resonator
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, without a resonator. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Borneo.

relation.label: 314.11-4-8 True board zithers without resonator sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard
314.11-4-8+421.132-62-8 True board zithers without resonator, sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard + sets of free reeds, with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard

term.label: 314.11-4-8 True board zithers without resonator sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, without a resonator. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by hammers or beaters. With keyboard.

term.label: 314.11-4-8+421.132-62-8 True board zithers without resonator, sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard + sets of free reeds, with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard
314.12 True board zithers with resonator
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer.

relation.label: 314.121 True board zithers with resonator bowl
314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.121 True board zithers with resonator bowl
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a bowl-shaped resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The resonator is a fruit shell or similar object, or an artificially carved equivalent. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer.

relation.label: 314.121-9 Mechanically driven true board zithers with resonator bowl

term.label: 314.121-9 Mechanically driven true board zithers with resonator bowl
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a bowl-shaped resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The resonator is a fruit shell or similar object, or an artificially carved equivalent. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. With mechanical drive.

relation.label: 314.121 True board zithers with resonator bowl

term.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Zither, Hackbrett, pianoforte. NB This is true of the early piano only; modern pianos have no bottom and are board zithers. Harpsichords and some clavichords are box zithers.

relation.label: 314.122-3 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by blowing
314.122-4 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by hammers or beaters
314.122-4-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard
314.122-5 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by the bare fingers
314.122-6 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by plectrum
314.122-6-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by plectrum, with keyboard
314.122-9 Mechanically driven true board zithers with resonator box (box zither)
314.122-6-8+421.222-62-8 Boxzither, sounded by plectrum, with keyboard + set of duct flutes, with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard
314.122-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) with keyboard

term.label: 314.122-3 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by blowing
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by blowing.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-4 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by hammers or beaters
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by hammers or beaters.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-4-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by hammers or beaters. With keyboard.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-5 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by the bare fingers.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-6 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by plectrum
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by plectrum.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-6-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by plectrum, with keyboard
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by plectrum. With keyboard.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-6-8+421.222-62-8 Boxzither, sounded by plectrum, with keyboard + set of duct flutes, with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) with keyboard

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.122-9 Mechanically driven true board zithers with resonator box (box zither)
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. With mechanical drive.

relation.label: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)

term.label: 314.2 Board zither variations
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer.

term.label: 314.21 Ground zithers
term.definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The ground is the string bearer; there is only one string. The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer. Malacca, Madagascar.

term.label: 314.22 Harp zithers
term.definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a rigid board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The strings pass over a notched bridge. The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer. Borneo, Africa: Bokongo, harp zither from the Bambinga people of the Uele district, Congo-Kinshasa.

term.label: 315 Trough zithers
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The instrument may consist solely of a trough, or a trough with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. Tanzania.

term.label: 315.1 Trough zithers without resonator
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The trough has no additional resonator.

relation.label: 315.1-5 Trough zithers without resonator sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 315.1-5 Trough zithers without resonator sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The trough has no additional resonator. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 315.2 Trough zithers with resonator
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The trough has a gourd or a similar object as a resonator attached, which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus.

term.label: 316 Frame zithers
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across a rigid open frame. The instrument may consist of a frame, or a frame with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus.

term.label: 316.1 Frame zithers without resonator
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across a rigid open frame. The instrument has no resonator. Perhaps amongst medieval psalteries.

term.label: 316.2 Frame zithers with resonator
term.definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across a rigid open frame. The instrument has a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. W. Africa, amongst the Kru (kani).

term.label: 32 Composite chordophones
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument.

term.label: 321 Lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table.

term.label: 321.1 Bow lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. Each string has its own flexible carrier. Africa (akam, kalangu, wambi).

term.label: 321.2 Yoke lutes or lyres
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar.

term.label: 321.21 Bowl lyres
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar. A natural or carved-out bowl serves as the resonator. Lyra, E. African lyre.

relation.label: 321.21-5 Bowl lyres sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 321.21-5 Bowl lyres sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar. A natural or carved-out bowl serves as the resonator. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 321.22 Box lyres
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar. A built-up wooden box serves as the resonator. Kithara, crwth.

term.label: 321.3 Handle lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle. Subsidiary necks, as e.g. in the Indian prasarini vina are disregarded, as also are lutes with strings distributed over several necks, like the harpolyre, and those like the lyre-guitars, in which the yoke is merely ornamental.

term.label: 321.31 Spike lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator.

relation.label: 321.312 Spike box lutes or spike guitars

term.label: 321.311 Spike bowl lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator that consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Iran, India, Indonesia.

relation.label: 321.311-7 Spike bowl lutes sounded by bowing

term.label: 321.311-7 Spike bowl lutes sounded by bowing
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator that consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Sounded by bowing.

term.label: 321.312 Spike box lutes or spike guitars
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator, which is built up from wood in the form of a box. Banjo, Egypt (rebab).

relation.label: 321.312-5 Spike box lutes or spike guitars sounded by the bare fingers
321.312-7 Spike box lutes or spike guitars sounded by bowing

term.label: 321.312-5 Spike box lutes or spike guitars sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator, which is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by the bare fingers.

relation.label: 321.312 Spike box lutes or spike guitars

term.label: 321.312-7 Spike box lutes or spike guitars sounded by bowing
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator, which is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by bowing.

relation.label: 321.312 Spike box lutes or spike guitars

term.label: 321.313 Spike tube lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through the walls of the tubular resonator. China, Indochina.

relation.label: 321.313-7 Spike tube lutes played by bowing

term.label: 321.313-7 Spike tube lutes played by bowing
321.32 Necked lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck.

relation.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.321 Necked bowl lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Mandolin, theorbo.

relation.label: 321.321-5 Necked bowl lutes sounded by the bare fingers
321.321-7 Necked bowl lutes sounded by bowing

term.label: 321.321-5 Necked bowl lutes sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 321.321-7 Necked bowl lutes sounded by bowing
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Sounded by bowing.

term.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. NB: lutes whose body is built up in the shape of a bowl are classified as bowl lutes. Violin, viol, guitar.

relation.label: 321.322-5 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by the bare fingers
321.322-7 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by bowing
321.322-71 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by bowing with a bow
321.322-8 Necked box lutes or necked guitars, with keyboard
321.322-9 Mechanically driven necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.322-5 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by the bare fingers.

relation.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.322-7 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by bowing
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by bowing.

relation.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.322-71 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by bowing with a bow
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by bowing with a bow.

relation.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.322-8 Necked box lutes or necked guitars, with keyboard
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. With keyboard.

relation.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.322-9 Mechanically driven necked box lutes or necked guitars
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. With mechanical drive.

relation.label: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars

term.label: 321.33 Half-spike lutes or tanged lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is neither attached to the resonator nor passes all the way through it, but terminates within the body. W.Africa.

term.label: 321.331 Half-spike or tanged bowl lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is neither attached to the resonator nor passes all the way through it, but terminates within the body. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl.

term.label: 321.332 Half-spike or tanged box lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is neither attached to the resonator nor passes all the way through it, but terminates within the body. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box.

term.label: 322 Harps
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck.

term.label: 322.1 Open harps
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar.

term.label: 322.11 Arched harps
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck curves away from the resonator. Burma and Africa.

relation.label: 322.11-5 Arched harps sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 322.111 Arched harps - Wachsmann type 1
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck rests on the bottom of the resonator 'like a spoon in a cup'. Uganda.

term.label: 322.112 Arched harps - Wachsmann type 2
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The tanged neck fits tightly into a hole at the narrow end of the resonator 'like a cork in a bottle'. Democratic Republic of Congo, Zande, Nzakara, Banda, Mangebetu.

term.label: 322.113 Arched harps - Wachsmann type 3
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. A carved finial extends from the resonator, usually in the form of a human head; it is often tied to the neck.

term.label: 322.11-5 Arched harps sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck curves away from the resonator. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 322.12 Angular harps
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck makes a sharp angle with the resonator. Assyria, Ancient Egypt, Ancient Korea, Mauretania ardin.

term.label: 322.2 Frame harps
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar.

term.label: 322.21 Frame harps without tuning action
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played. All medieval harps.

relation.label: 322.211 Diatonic frame harps without tuning action
322.212 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action

term.label: 322.211 Diatonic frame harps without tuning action
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned diatonically. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played.

term.label: 322.212 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played.

relation.label: 322.212.1 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in one plane
322.212.2 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in two planes crossing one another
322.212.3 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in two or more parallel planes

term.label: 322.212.1 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in one plane
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played. Most of the older chromatic harps.

relation.label: 322.212 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action

term.label: 322.212.2 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in two planes crossing one another
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically, with the strings in two planes crossing one another. The Lyon chromatic harp.

relation.label: 322.212 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action

term.label: 322.212.3 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in two or more parallel planes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically, with the strings in two or more parallel planes. Triple harp.

relation.label: 322.212 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action

term.label: 322.22 Frame harps with tuning action
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The strings can be shortened by mechanical action.

term.label: 322.221 Frame harps with manual action
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The strings can be shortened by mechanical hand-levers. Hook harp, dital harp, harpinella.

relation.label: 322.221-5 Frame harps with manual action sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 322.221-5 Frame harps with manual action sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The strings can be shortened by mechanical hand-levers. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 322.222 Frame harps with pedal action
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The tuning can be altered by pedals.

relation.label: 322.222-5 Frame harps with pedal action sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 322.222-5 Frame harps with pedal action sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The tuning can be altered by pedals. Sounded by the bare fingers.

term.label: 323 Spike harps with tall stringholders
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable; a tall stringholder or bridge holds the strings at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body resembles a spike lute, with a neck bisecting a calabash resonator.

relation.label: 323.1 Arched spike harps with tall stringholders
323.2 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes

term.label: 323.1 Arched spike harps with tall stringholders
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable. The strings are attached at different levels to a tall stringholder; their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body resembles a spike lute, with a neck bisecting a calabash resonator. The neck curves away from the resonator. Guinea (bolon), Gambia (simbango).

term.label: 323.2 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable. The strings pass over a tall notched bridge at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body, like a spike lute, has a string bearer that passes diametrically through the resonator. A line joining the lower ends of the strings would be perpendicular to the neck. Gambia, kora.

relation.label: 323.2-5 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes sounded by the bare fingers

term.label: 323.2-5 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes sounded by the bare fingers
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable. The strings pass over a tall notched bridge at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body, like a spike lute, has a string bearer that passes diametrically through the resonator. A line joining the lower ends of the strings would be perpendicular to the neck. Sounded by the bare fingers.

relation.label: 323.2 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes

term.label: 324 Tanged harps with tall stringholders
term.definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable; a tall stringholder or bridge holds the strings at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. A carved extension of the resonator forms the socket for the shaft of the neck (illustrated in S.C. DeVale 'African Harps: Construction, Decoration and Sound' Sounding Forms ed. M-T Brincard, [New York, 1989] p.56 figure 6.3a).

term.label: 33 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums'
term.definition: A single or double stretched string is fixed at one end to a handle. At the other end it is attached to a membrane covering a hole cut out of the base of a resonator, resembling a drum. The string bearer and resonator are organically united so that they cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the string lies at right angles to the membrane. By adjusting the handle, the player braces the string to alter its tension and change its pitch.

relation.label: 331 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums' with loose string attached to the drum-head
332 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums' with string attached to the end of a neck and to the drum-head

term.label: 331 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums' with loose string attached to the drum-head
term.definition: A single or double stretched string is fixed at one end to a handle. At the other end it is attached to a membrane covering a hole cut out of the base of a resonator, resembling a drum. The string bearing handle and the resonator are united by the string so that they cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the string lies at right angles to the membrane. By adjusting the position of the handle, the player braces the loose string to alter its tension and change its pitch. India (anandalahari).

term.label: 332 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums' with string attached to the end of a neck and to the drum-head
term.definition: A single string is stretched between two fixed points. At one end it is attached to a handle in the form of a neck or yoke. At the other end it is fixed to a membrane covering a hole cut out of the base of a resonator, resembling a drum. The string bearer and resonator are organically united so that they cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the string lies at right angles to the membrane. By adjusting the handle, the player braces the string to alter its tension and change its pitch. India (gopi yantra).

term.label: 4 Aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. In this group also are classed those reed instruments sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator.

term.label: 41 Free aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. In this group also are classed those reed instruments sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument.

term.label: 411 Displacement free aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream meets a sharp edge, or a sharp edge is moved through the air. In either case a periodic displacement of air occurs to alternate flanks of the edge. Whip, sword-blade.

term.label: 412 Interruptive free aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. In this group also are classed those reed instruments sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is interrupted periodically.

term.label: 412.1 Idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella.

relation.label: 412.11 Idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds: paired reeds
412.1-9 Mechanically driven idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds

term.label: 412.11 Idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds: paired reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. Two lamellae make a gap which closes periodically during their vibration. A split grass-blade.

term.label: 412.12 Beating reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. A lamella periodically opens and closes an aperture. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella.

term.label: 412.121 Individual beating reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator.
