In individual beating reeds the air-stream is directed against a single lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamella periodically opens and closes an aperture. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. The reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. British Columbia.

term.label: 412.122 Sets of beating reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of beating reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae periodically open and close a set of apertures. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Such reeds may have a resonator, in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. The earlier reed stops of organs.

relation.label: 412-122-8 Sets of beating reeds with keyboard

term.label: 412.13 Free reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamella vibrates through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes.

term.label: 412.131 (Individual) free reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In individual free reeds the air-stream is directed against a single lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamella vibrates through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. Such reeds may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. Single-note motor horn.

term.label: 412.132 Sets of free reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. NB: in instruments like the Chinese sheng, where the bamboo pipes act as an acoustic coupler, the fingerholes do not serve to modify the pitch and are therefore not equivalent to the fingerholes of other pipes. Reed organ, mouthorgan, accordion.

relation.label: 412.132-6-9 Mechanically driven sets of free reeds with air reservoir
412.132-62 Sets of free reeds with flexible air reservoir
412.132-9 Mechanically driven sets of free reeds
412.132-62-8 Sets of free reeds with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard

term.label: 412.132-62 Sets of free reeds with flexible air reservoir
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With flexible air reservoir.

term.label: 412.132-62-8 Sets of free reeds with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound. The instrument has a flexible air reservoir. The mechanism admitting air to the reeds is operated by a keyboard.

term.label: 412.132-6-9 Mechanically driven sets of free reeds with air reservoir
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With air reservoir. With mechanical drive.

term.label: 412.132-9 Mechanically driven sets of free reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With mechanical drive.

term.label: 412.14 Ribbon reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against the edge of a stretched band or ribbon. The acoustics of this process have not yet been studied. British Columbia.

term.label: 412.15 Retreating reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The reeds are of grass and similar stems with longitudinal slits.

term.label: 412.1-9 Mechanically driven idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. With mechanical drive.

term.label: 412.2 Non-idiophonic interruptive instruments
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The interruptive agent is not a reed.

term.label: 412.21 Rotating aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The interruptive agent is not a reed. The interruptive agent rotates in its own plane. Sirens, whirring disc.

term.label: 412.22 Whirling aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The interruptive agent is not a reed. The interruptive agent turns on its axis. Bull-roarer, ventilating fan.

term.label: 412-122-8 Sets of beating reeds with keyboard
term.definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of beating reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae periodically open and close a set of apertures. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Such reeds may have a resonator, in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With a keyboard.

term.label: 413 Plosive aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock.

term.label: 413.1 Explosive aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock when it is forced out. Pop guns.

term.label: 413.2 Implosive aerophones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock when it is forced in. W. Africa, shantu.

term.label: 42 Wind instruments proper
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself.

relation.label: 420 Edge-tone instruments that are not flutes

term.label: 420 Edge-tone instruments that are not flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The hole through which the instrument is blown opens onto a narrow chamber, and has an exit hole diametrically opposite it. Widgeon whistles.

term.label: 421 Edge instruments or flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge to excite a column of air in a tube or a body of air in a cavity.

relation.label: 421.2 Flutes with duct or duct flutes

term.label: 421.1 Flutes without duct
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips.

term.label: 421.11 End-blown flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube.

term.label: 421.112.1 Open panpipes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a t.

relation.label: 421.112 Sets of end-blown flutes or panpipes

term.label: 421.112.11 Open (raft) panpipes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are open. The pipes are tied together in the form of a board, or they are made by drilling tubes in a board. China.

term.label: 421.112.12 Open bundle (pan-) pipes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are open. The pipes are tied together in a round bundle. Solomon Is., New Britain, New Ireland, Admiralty Is.

term.label: 421.112.2 Stopped panpipes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are closed. Europe, S. America.

relation.label: 421.112 Sets of end-blown flutes or panpipes

term.label: 421.112.3 Mixed open and stopped panpipes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. Some of the pipes have open lower ends, others are closed. Solomon Is., S. America.

term.label: 421.12 Side-blown flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube.

term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the flute is open.

term.label: 421.121.11 Open side-blown flutes without fingerholes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. term.label: 421.121.12 Open side-blown flutes with fingerholes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the flute is open. The instrument has fingerholes. European flute.

term.label: 421.121.2 Partly-stopped side-blown flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole. N. W. Borneo.

term.label: 421.121.3 Stopped side-blown flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is stopped.

term.label: 421.121.31 Stopped side-blown flutes without fingerholes

The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube has a fixed stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. Apparently non-existent.

term.label: 421.121.312 Stopped side-blown flutes without fingerholes, adjustable stopped lower end
term.definition: Stopped side-blown flutes without fingerholes, with adjustable stopped lower end (piston flutes) The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube has an adjustable stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. (piston flutes) Malacca, New Guinea.

term.label: 421.121.32 Stopped side-blown flutes with fingerholes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is stopped. The instrument has fingerholes. E. Bengal, Malacca.

term.label: 421.122 Sets of side-blown flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow stream of air is directed against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube. Two or more flutes are played together.

term.label: 421.122.1 Sets of open side-blown flutes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where narrow stream of air is directed against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube. Two or more flutes are played together. The distal ends of the flutes are open. Chamber flute-orum.

term.label: 421.122.2 Sets of stopped side-blown flutes
term.definition: Sets of stopped side-blown flutes The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow stream of air is directed against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube. Two or more flutes are played together. The distal ends of the flutes are closed. N. W. Brazil (among the Siusi).

term.label: 421.13 Vessel flutes (without distinct beak)
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge as the player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a vessel. Brazil (Karaja), Lower Congo (Bafiote).

term.label: 422.211.2-5 (Single) wind-cap clarinets with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The tubular body has a cylindrical bore, and fingerholes. The instrument is tuned by altering the length of the air column. With wind-cap.

relation.label: 422.211.2 (Single) clarinets with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes

term.label: 422.212 (Single) clarinets with conical bore
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The tubular body has a conical bore. The instrument is tuned by altering the length of the air column. Saxophone.

term.label: 422.22 Sets of reedpipes with single reeds
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. In each pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Egypt (zummara).

relation.label: 422.22-5 Sets of wind-cap reedpipes with single reeds
422.22-62 Sets of clarinets with flexible air reservoir

term.label: 422.22-5 Sets of wind-cap reedpipes with single reeds
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. In each pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With wind-cap.

relation.label: 422.22 Sets of reedpipes with single reeds

term.label: 422.22-62 Sets of clarinets with flexible air reservoir

relation.label: 422.22 Sets of reedpipes with single reeds

term.label: 422.3 Reedpipes with free reeds
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a lamella. The reed vibrates through [at] a closely fitted frame in the wall of a tube. The instrument is tuned by altering the length of the air column. There must be fingerholes in the pipe, otherwise the instrument belongs to the free reeds. S.E. Asia.

term.label: 422.31 Single reedpipes with free reed
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a lamella. The reed vibrates through [at] a closely fitted frame in the wall of an individual tube. The instrument is tuned by altering the length of the air column. There must be fingerholes in the pipe, otherwise the instrument belongs to the free reeds.

term.label: 422.32 Double reedpipes with free reeds
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a lamella. The reed vibrates through [at] a closely fitted frame in the wall of a tube. The instrument has two pipes with reeds. It is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. There must be fingerholes in the pipes, otherwise the instrument belongs to the free reeds.

term.label: 422.33 Horns with free reed
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a lamella or lamellae. The reed vibrates through [at] a closely fitted frame set into a horn. Burma.

term.label: 422.4 Dilating reeds
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent flow of an air stream produced by means of one or more longitudinal slits in a grass or similar stem.

term.label: 422.41 Dilating reeds without fingerholes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent flow of an air stream produced by means of one or more longitudinal slits in a grass or similar stem. There are no fingerholes.

term.label: 422.42 Dilating reeds with fingerholes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent flow of an air stream produced by means of one or more longitudinal slits in a grass or similar stem. There are fingerholes. Sami (fadno).

term.label: 423 Labrosones (or lip-reed instruments)
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate.

term.label: 423.1 Natural labrosones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The instrument has no extra devices to alter its pitch.

term.label: 423.11 Conches
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. A conch shell serves as a trumpet.

term.label: 423.111 End-blown conches
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. An end-blown conch shell serves as a trumpet.

term.label: 423.111.1 End-blown conches without mouthpiece
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. A conch shell serves as a trumpet. It is end-blown, and has no mouthpiece. India.

term.label: 423.111.2 End-blown conches with mouthpiece
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. A conch shell serves as a trumpet. It is end-blown, and has material added to the shell form a mouthpiece. Japan (rappakai).

term.label: 423.112 Side-blown conches
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. A side-blown conch shell serves as a trumpet. Oceania.

term.label: 423.12 Tubular labrosones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a whole tube.

term.label: 423.121 End-blown labrosones
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittent access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate. The body of the instrument is a whole tube. The instrument is end-blown.

The body of the instrument is a whole tube that is neither curved nor folded. The instrument is end-blown, and has material added to the tube form a mouthpiece. Almost world-wide.

term.label: 424 Membranopipes
term.definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The air column is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a membrane that periodically opens and closes an aperture.

term.label: 5 Electrophones
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources, electronically stored data, electronic circuitry or materials that produce acoustic sound (unmodified acoustic instruments with attached microphones or pickups are classed within groups 1-4, according to the primary source of sound).

relation.label: 53 Analogue electronic instruments, modules and components

term.label: 51 Electro-acoustic instruments and devices
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms (often resembling traditional acoustic instruments) and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers.

term.label: 511 Electro-acoustic idiophones
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. Material vibrates mechanically owing to its solidity and elasticity to provide input to a transducer (pick-up).

term.label: 512 Electro-acoustic membranophones
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The electric signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. A tightly stretched membrane vibrates to provide input to a transducer (pick-up).

term.label: 513 Electro-acoustic chordophones
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. One or more strings stretched between fixed points vibrate to provide input to a transducer (pick-up).

term.label: 514 Electro-acoustic aerophones
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are produced using materials that generate acoustic sound, or by mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of acoustic, vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. Vibrating bodies of air or vibrating reeds provide input to transducers (microphones or pick-ups).

term.label: 515 Transducers
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The acoustic or mechanical vibration is transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current.

term.label: 52 Electromechanical instruments and devices
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current.

term.label: 521 Tone wheel instruments
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The patterns are encoded on a wheel and read electromagnetically or electrostatically.

term.label: 522 Photo-electric electromechanical instruments
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The encoded patterns are read photoelectrically.

term.label: 523 Record/playback devices
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The encoded patterns are recorded, and read in playing back electromagnetically or electrostatically.

term.label: 524 Electromechanical samplers
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. The encoded patterns are samples.

term.label: 525 Electromechanical sound processing devices
term.definition: Electrical signals are passed to a loudspeaker to produce sound. The signals are generated using mechanically driven signal sources. Modules and configurations of vibratory mechanisms and electronic circuitry such as transducers and amplifiers. Configurations of (electrically excited) silent, mechanical moving parts with encoded patterns and electronic circuitry. The movement enables the encoded patterns to be transduced into an analogue fluctuation of an electric current. Devices to modify signals electromechanically.
